Dr. Alex Kalynychenko: A lecturer at the University of Toronto Mississauga, Department of Geography, Geomatics and Environment, who is giving a lecture on Spatial Analysis.
University of Toronto Mississauga: A university campus where the lecture on Spatial Analysis is taking place.
Spatial Analysis: A type of geographical analysis which seeks to understand patterns of human behavior and its spatial expression in terms of mathematics and geometry.
ESRI: A supplier of Geographic Information System (GIS) software, web GIS and geodatabase management applications. Mentioned as the source of some information and as the creator of a webinar and software extensions used in spatial analysis.
Carl Steinitz: A renowned scholar in the field of geodesign, known for his practical applications of geodesign principles.
Longley et al. (2015): The source of the text discussing redistricting, gerrymandering, centrality, and analysis of surfaces.
ArcGIS Pro extensions: Specially designed tools to enhance the functionality of ArcGIS Pro, a GIS software. These extensions are used for various spatial analysis tasks, such as 3D analysis, market trends analysis, geostatistical analysis, image analysis, network analysis, and more.
Aristotle: Ancient Greek philosopher mentioned in the context of known vs unknown limitations.
Machine Learning and AI: Set of data-driven algorithms and techniques that automate the prediction, classification, and clustering of data. Deep learning, a subset of machine learning, uses artificial neural networks to learn from data.
Big data analytics: The process of examining large and varied data sets to uncover hidden patterns, unknown correlations, market trends, customer preferences and other useful information. In the context of the lecture, it refers to tools in ArcGIS Pro that can transform large amounts of spatial data into manageable information.
ESRI 2024: The source of the text discussing modeling and scripting in geoprocessing, specifically using Python and ModelBuilder.
Python: A high-level, interpreted programming language often used for scripting in geoprocessing.
ModelBuilder: A visual programming language for building geoprocessing workflows in ESRI software.
Zandbergen (2024): The source of the text discussing the purpose of area-based analyses in geography.
Area-Based Analyses: A method of simplifying the Earth's geography by ascribing characteristics to entire areas rather than individual points.
Polygon: A geometric figure with multiple sides, used in this context to measure areas in geographical analyses.
Redistricting: The process of drawing electoral district boundaries, often following a census.
Gerrymandering: The practice of manipulating the boundaries of an electoral constituency to favor a particular party.
23rd Congressional District: An old electoral district in California, transformed into the 24th District after redistricting.
24th District: A new, more compact electoral district in California, formed after redistricting.
Centrality: A statistical measure indicating the center of a distribution.
Mean: A measure of central tendency found by taking the average of a set of values.
Median: A measure of central tendency that separates the higher half from the lower half of a data set.
Mode: The value that appears most frequently in a data set.
Centroid: The two-dimensional equivalent of the mean, summarizing the locations of a set of points.
U. S. Bureau of the Census: The U.S. government agency responsible for producing data about the American people and economy, including the results of the census.
Dispersion: A measure of how spread out the values in a data set are.
Standard Deviation: A measure of the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of values.
Variance: The average of the squared differences from the mean in a data set.
Range: The difference between the highest and lowest values in a data set.
RMSE: Root Mean Square Error, a measure of the differences between values predicted by a model and the values actually observed.
Analysis of Surfaces: A method of examining geographical features such as slope, travel on a surface, watersheds, and channels.
DEM: Digital Elevation Model, a 3D representation of a terrain's surface.
2015: The year mentioned in the source of the text, possibly the year of publication of the referenced work by Longley et al.
https://www.travelassociates.com/: A website URL, likely related to travel or tourism.
Orange County DEM: Digital Elevation Model of Orange County, a 3D representation of a terrain's surface.
river channels: The physical pathways through which a river flows.
Santa Ana River: A river in Southern California that flows from the San Bernardino Mountains to the Pacific Ocean.
gorge: A narrow valley between hills or mountains, typically with steep rocky walls and a stream running through it.
Pacific: The Pacific Ocean, the largest and deepest of Earth's oceanic divisions.
Seal Beach: A coastal city located in Orange County, California.
Newport Beach: A coastal city in Southern California, where the Santa Ana River actually empties into the Pacific Ocean.
geodesign process: A design and planning method which tightly couples the creation of design proposals with impact simulations informed by geographic contexts.
location-allocation problems: Problems in operations research and logistics focusing on the optimal location of facilities and the allocation of resources.
p-median problem: An optimization problem in location theory, seeking the optimal locations for a given number of facilities to minimize the sum of distances to all clients.
coverage problem: A problem in location theory aiming to minimize the maximum distance from any demand point to a facility.
Hakimiâ€™s theorem: A theorem in network theory stating that optimal locations are at vertices or demand points.
routing problems: Problems in operations research concerning the optimal paths or routes through a network.
shortest-path problem: A problem in graph theory requiring the determination of a path between two vertices such that the sum of the weights of its constituent edges is minimized.
traveling-salesman problem (TSP): An optimization problem in computer science and operations research which asks for the shortest possible route that visits a given set of cities and returns to the origin city.
orienteering problem: An optimization problem where the goal is to select a subset of locations to visit in order to maximize the total score, subject to a time constraint.
Sears: An American chain of department stores. In this context, it refers to a system used by Sears drivers for scheduling and navigation.
hypothesis testing: A statistical method used to make inferences or draw conclusions about a larger population based on a sample of data.
randomization tests: Statistical tests that generate many samples according to the null hypothesis and calculate the test statistic for each sample.
vegetation cover class: A classification of the type and amount of vegetation covering the ground in a specific area.
elevation: The height above a given level, especially sea level.
Santa Barbara: A city on the central California coast, north of Los Angeles.
ArcGIS Pro: A popular geographic information system (GIS) application for creating and working with spatial data on your desktop.
geodesign principles: Principles guiding the field of geodesign, which combines geography with design by integrating planning and spatial analysis techniques.
Quiz 4: A test that will be administered via Quercus next week, covering materials of Week 9&10 Spatial Analysis I&II and recommended readings.
Quercus: The platform through which Quiz 4 will be administered.
Week 9&10 Spatial Analysis I&II: The materials that will be covered in Quiz 4. This includes both the first and second parts of a spatial analysis course.
Recommended readings: Additional materials suggested for study in preparation for Quiz 4.
Lab 3: An event or session that will take place on Thursday, March 13, 2025.
Thursday, March 13, 2025: The date on which Lab 3 will occur.
